message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound and FNAC findings suggest a follicular neoplasm, which requires histopathological examination of the tissue after lobectomy. Among the given options, only option (C) describes the diagnostic criteria for follicular carcinoma, which includes capsular and vascular invasion by well-differentiated follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia. Psammoma bodies may be present in papillary carcinoma, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are seen in medullary carcinoma. Well-differentiated follicular cells without vascular invasion may indicate follicular adenoma, but it is not diagnostic for carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound findings suggest a suspicious thyroid nodule and the FNAC results suggest a follicular neoplasm. The histopathological finding that is diagnostic for follicular carcinoma is follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia, with capsular and vascular invasion. Presence of Psammoma bodies is a characteristic finding of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. Well-differentiated follicular cells without vascular invasion are seen in follicular adenoma. Hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's clinical presentation suggests thyroid cancer, and the ultrasound findings indicate that the mass has suspicious features for malignancy. The FNAC detected follicular cells suspicious of follicular neoplasm, which raises the concern for follicular carcinoma. The histopathological finding that is diagnostic for follicular carcinoma is the presence of follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia, with capsular and vascular invasion. Psammoma bodies may be present in papillary thyroid carcinoma, well-differentiated follicular cells without vascular invasion may be seen in benign follicular adenomas, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are seen in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound findings, along with the suspicious FNAC results, suggest a follicular neoplasm. In order for the mass to be classified as malignant, it must show capsular and/or vascular invasion. The other options are not diagnostic of malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the mass on ultrasound, the results of FNAC, and the suspicion of a follicular neoplasm suggest the most likely diagnosis is follicular carcinoma. Among the options, only option C describes the histopathological finding of a follicular carcinoma: follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia, with capsular and vascular invasion. Psammoma bodies are associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, well-differentiated follicular cells without vascular invasion may suggest follicular adenoma, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound findings suggest a thyroid carcinoma, and the FNAC results suggest a follicular neoplasm. Capsular and vascular invasion are necessary for the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. Presence of Psammoma bodies is not specific for any thyroid neoplasm, well-differentiated follicular cells without vascular invasion are suggestive of a benign follicular adenoma, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient’s symptoms, ultrasound findings, and FNAC results, the most likely diagnosis is follicular neoplasm. The diagnostic finding on histopathology for follicular carcinoma is follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia, with capsular and vascular invasion. Option A is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma, option B is associated with follicular adenoma, and option D is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound finding, as well as the FNAC result, suggest a follicular neoplasm. The most important histopathological finding for diagnosis of follicular carcinoma is capsular and vascular invasion by well-differentiated follicular cells. Psammoma bodies may be present in both benign and malignant thyroid nodules, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are not relevant in diagnosing follicular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, imaging findings, and cytology report all suggest a follicular neoplasm. The definitive diagnosis of follicular carcinoma requires histological evidence of capsular and/or vascular invasion. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Option (A) is a characteristic finding of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Option (B) describes a benign follicular adenoma. Option (D) is not related to follicular neoplasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, ultrasound findings, and FNAC suspicion of follicular neoplasm, suggest a follicular thyroid carcinoma. The key diagnostic feature of follicular thyroid carcinoma is the presence of capsular and vascular invasion by well-differentiated follicular cells that lack nuclear atypia. Psammoma bodies can be seen in both benign and malignant thyroid tumors, and hyperplastic parafollicular C cells are not specific to follicular thyroid carcinoma.
